item.title: Salt in tea? Recipe sparks tension between U.S. and U.K.
item.description: The American embassy says the nation's relationship with the U.K. is in "hot water" after a U.S. chemist suggested British tea is missing salt – but elsewhere in the world, that ingredient isn't unusual.

item.title: U.S. scientist stirs salty debate about British tea
item.description: The tradition of tea drinking runs deep in Britain, but trouble is brewing over the best brew thanks to one U.S. scientist. Ian Lee has the story.

item.title: Countries halt funds to U.N. agency over claim staff involved in Hamas attack
item.description: Australia, Italy, the U.K. and other key donors halted funding to U.N. agency over claim staff involved in Hamas' attack on Israel on Oct. 7.

item.title: Israeli troops take CBS News crew into southern Gaza
item.description: A CBS News crew crossed into southern Gaza with Israeli soldiers of the 55th Brigade, 98th Paratroopers Division. Known as the "Tip of the Spear Brigade," they have been fighting against Hamas since early December. Charlie D'Agata reports from Gaza.

item.title: Houthis target U.S. destroyer in latest round of missile attacks
item.description: The attack on the destroyer USS Carney marked a further escalation in the biggest confrontation at sea the U.S. Navy has seen in the Middle East in decades.

item.title: Aryna Sabalenka wins back-to-back Australian Open titles
item.description: Aryna Sabalenka ensured she wasn't a one-hit wonder by clinching back-to-back Australian Open titles with a win over Zheng Qinwen on Saturday.

item.title: Israel says it will stop UNRWA from operating in Gaza after war
item.description: Israel's foreign ministry says it will stop UNRWA, the U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees, from operating in Gaza once the war between Israel and Hamas ends. Israel has accused several UNRWA staff of being involved in Hamas Oct. 7 terror attack, which killed hundreds and sparked the war. It comes a day after the U.N.'s top court ruled Israel must do more to prevent genocide in Gaza. CBS News' Deborah Patta is in Tel Aviv with more.

item.title: He survived the Holocaust; her father was a Nazi soldier. They fell in love.
item.description: Some predicted Werner and Martha Salinger's marriage wouldn't last, but their love thrived against all odds.

item.title: U.N. court orders Israel to prevent genocide in Gaza, but not to cease fire
item.description: The International Court of Justice says Israel's actions in Gaza are sufficient to warrant the court hearing a genocide case brought by South Africa.

item.title: U.N. stops short of ordering Gaza cease-fire
item.description: The United Nations' International Court of Justice ruled Friday that Israel must do more to prevent genocide in Gaza as Israel continues its fight against Hamas, but stopped short of ordering a cease-fire.

item.title: U.S. southern border sees record number of migrant crossings
item.description: U.S. Border Patrol processed more than 302,000 migrants at the southern border in December, a monthly record high. However, U.S. officials have seen a notable drop in daily illegal crossings so far in January. Camilo Montoya-Galvez reports from Eagle Pass, Texas.

item.title: 93 Americans died after cosmetic surgery in Dominican Republic over 14 years
item.description: The CDC noted that so-called medical tourism​ is becoming more common among Americans seeking cheaper procedures quickly.

item.title: South Korean health officials urge against eating fried toothpicks
item.description: In videos posted online, users are seen deep-frying toothpicks and adding seasonings to them before eating them.

item.title: U.S. halts U.N. agency funding over claim staffers took part in Oct. 7 attack
item.description: The U.N. agency that serves Palestinians says it has fired staffers accused by Israel of participating in Hamas' Oct. 7 terror attack.

item.title: King Charles III admitted to hospital for enlarged prostate treatment
item.description: "His Majesty's condition is benign and he will attend hospital next week for a corrective procedure" for an enlarged prostate, Buckingham Palace said of King Charles III.

item.title: Mikaela Shiffrin hospitalized after crash on 2026 Olympics course
item.description: Mikaela Shiffrin, who has a record 95 World Cup wins, was helped off the course with her left boot raised off the snow.

item.title: British Museum reveals record-breaking treasure finds by public
item.description: There were over 1,300 treasure finds made by the public in 2022, and most of the items were discovered by people metal-detecting, the museum said.

item.title: Anxiety for displaced Palestinians crowding into Gaza-Egypt buffer zone
item.description: Israel has said a narrow buffer zone along Gaza's border with Egypt "must be in our hands," but it's filling up with displaced Palestinians.

item.title: Klimt painting to be auctioned after being lost for 100 years
item.description: The painting is being auctioned as part of an agreement to turn in art once confiscated by the Nazis.

item.title: How a tiny invasive ant is forcing lions to change the way they hunt
item.description: A study highlights the potentially profound impacts of invasive species, which are spreading at an increasing rate.

item.title: Coco Gauff eliminated from Australian Open in loss to Aryna Sabalenka
item.description: Coco Gauff previously defeated Aryna Sabalenka in the U.S. Open final last September to claim her first Grand Slam title.

item.title: CIA director to travel to Europe for fourth round of Gaza hostage talks
item.description: The CIA director will meet in France with the head of Israel's Mossad and the prime minister of Qatar.

item.title: U.K. army chief says citizens should be ready to fight in possible land war
item.description: "Taking preparatory steps to enable placing our societies on a war footing when needed are now not merely desirable but essential," British Gen. Patrick Sanders said.

item.title: Guns, coins found in wrecks of ships that vanished with 129 on board
item.description: In 1848, the HMS Erebus and HMS Terror were lost in the frigid waters off the coast of Canada. None of the 129 men on board survived.

item.title: France's Constitutional Council scraps parts of divisive immigration law
item.description: Among the measures rejected by France's constitutional authority were articles making it harder for immigrants to bring in their families and limiting access to welfare.

item.title: Ex-Spain soccer president facing trial for unwanted kiss at Women's World Cup
item.description: State prosecutors accused Luis Rubiales of sexual assault and for allegedly trying to coerce Jenni Hermoso to publicly support him in the public backlash against him.

item.title: U.N. says Israeli tank fire on Gaza shelter killed at least 12 people
item.description: A senior U.N. official says a deadly Israeli strike on a shelter for civilians in Gaza shows a "blatant disregard of basic rules of war."

item.title: Man gets death sentence for arson attack that killed 36 at anime studio
item.description: Shinji Aoba stormed into Kyoto Animation's No. 1 studio on July 18, 2019, and set it on fire.

item.title: Josef Fritzl, who held daughter captive, may be moved to regular prison
item.description: An Austrian court says Josef Fritzl, who held his daughter captive for 24 years and raped her thousands of times, can be moved out of psychiatric detention.

item.title: Father-daughter duo finds success with TV channel airing only classics
item.description: Nestled in the English countryside is the unlikely headquarters of one of the U.K.'s top independent TV channels.
